Norms and transfers

Jul 22, 2020

I suggested in this post that it may be possible to prove May nilpotence by a Devinatz-Hopkins-Smith style nilpotence argument, by going up the symmetric power filtration of . The suggestion in that post doesn’t exactly work as written, but Jeremy observed a fix in a special case that might generalize. I’d like to explain this observation in this post.

First, setup. Let be an -ring, and let . We want to show that . Let’s localize at . Note that , so we can assume that in for some . Then, we just need to show that .

Now, the symmetric power filtration is filtered, so the unit factors through some . Jeremy’s argument assumes that the unit factors through . Since is zero, the unit is null, and so the map is null. If was a ring, then this would immediately imply that is zero; but it’s not (and this was the problem in the previous post).

However, one can still argue that if the map is null (and ), then . To see this, note that there is a cofiber sequence

and so the fact that the unit in is null implies that the unit map lifts along the transfer ; in other words, there is a map such that the composite

is the unit.

Now, we know that . In general, if is the norm, then there is a relation . At an odd prime, we get

this is basically the binomial theorem. In any case, we see that

for any integer , so , and thus in . Since the unit of factors through the transfer, this forces , as desired.

In a future post, we will discuss what happens if the unit factors through instead.
